channel.title: NPR Topics: Home Page Top Stories
channel.description: Top stories in the U.S. and world news, politics, health, science, business, music, arts and culture. Nonprofit journalism with a mission. This is NPR.

image.title: NPR Topics: Home Page Top Stories

item.title: U.S. ice dancers Madison Chock and Evan Bates win Olympic silver, in a stunning upset
item.description: Chock and Bates, four-time Olympians, were heavily favored for gold. But they lost by less than two points to a French duo who has been clouded by controversy involving their former partners.
item.content:encoded:
Chock and Bates, four-time Olympians, were heavily favored for gold. But they lost by less than two points to a French duo who has been clouded by controversy involving their former partners.

(Image credit: Francisco Seco)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: AI brings Supreme Court decisions to life
item.description: Like it or not, the justices are about to see AI versions of themselves, speaking words that they spoke in court but that were not heard contemporaneously by anyone except those in the courtroom.
item.content:encoded:
Like it or not, the justices are about to see AI versions of themselves, speaking words that they spoke in court but that were not heard contemporaneously by anyone except those in the courtroom.

(Image credit: On The Docket)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: These monks' walk for peace captivated Americans. It ends this week
item.description: A group of Buddhist monks walked from Fort Worth, Texas, to Washington, D.C., in the name of peace. The 108-day pilgrimage captivated Americans.
item.content:encoded:
A group of Buddhist monks walked from Fort Worth, Texas, to Washington, D.C., in the name of peace. The 108-day pilgrimage captivated Americans.

(Image credit: Rahmat Gul)
item.dc:creator: Sarah Ventre

item.title: El Paso airspace closure due to use of U.S. military anti-drone technology
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration abruptly closed the airspace around El Paso, only to reopen it hours later. The bizarre episode pointed to a lack of coordination between the FAA and the Pentagon.
item.content:encoded:
The Federal Aviation Administration abruptly closed the airspace around El Paso, only to reopen it hours later. The bizarre episode pointed to a lack of coordination between the FAA and the Pentagon.

(Image credit: Morgan Lee)
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: 'Dawson's Creek' star James Van Der Beek has died at 48
item.description: Van Der Beek played Dawson Leery on the hit show Dawson's Creek. He announced his colon cancer diagnosis in 2024.
item.content:encoded:
Van Der Beek played Dawson Leery on the hit show Dawson's Creek. He announced his colon cancer diagnosis in 2024.

(Image credit: Valerie Macon)
item.dc:creator: Mia Venkat

item.title: A Jan. 6 rioter pardoned by Trump was convicted of sexually abusing children
item.description: A handyman from Florida who received a pardon from President Trump for storming the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was convicted on state charges of child sex abuse and exposing himself to a child.
item.content:encoded: A handyman from Florida who received a pardon from President Trump for storming the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was convicted on state charges of child sex abuse and exposing himself to a child.
item.dc:creator: Tom Dreisbach

item.title: A country-pop newcomer's debut is your reinvention album of 2026
item.description: August Ponthier's Everywhere Isn't Texas is as much a fully realized introduction as a complete revival. Its an existential debut that asks: How, exactly, does the artist fit in here?
item.content:encoded:
is Ponthier's opus to the wonders of self-discovery, a pristine debut about how exhilarating and even terrifying it can be to keep changing all your plans.'/>

August Ponthier's Everywhere Isn't Texas is as much a fully realized introduction as a complete revival. Its an existential debut that asks: How, exactly, does the artist fit in here?

(Image credit: Julian Buchan)
item.dc:creator: Hazel Cills

item.title: U.S. unexpectedly adds 130,000 jobs in January after a weak 2025
item.description: U.S. employers added 130,000 jobs in January as the unemployment rate dipped to 4.3% from 4.4% in December. Annual revisions show that job growth last year was far weaker than initially reported.
item.content:encoded:
U.S. employers added 130,000 jobs in January as the unemployment rate dipped to 4.3% from 4.4% in December. Annual revisions show that job growth last year was far weaker than initially reported.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Greetings from Mexico City's iconic boulevard, where a dog on a bike steals the show
item.description: Every week, more than 100,000 people ride bikes, skates and rollerblades past some of the best-known parts of Mexico's capital. And sometimes their dogs join them too.
item.content:encoded: Every week, more than 100,000 people ride bikes, skates and rollerblades past some of the best-known parts of Mexico's capital. And sometimes their dogs join them too.
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta

item.title: February may be short on days -- but it boasts a long list of new books
item.description: The shortest month of the year is packed with highly anticipated new releases, including books from Michael Pollan, Tayari Jones and the late Nobel laureate Mario Vargas Llosa.
item.content:encoded: The shortest month of the year is packed with highly anticipated new releases, including books from Michael Pollan, Tayari Jones and the late Nobel laureate Mario Vargas Llosa.
item.dc:creator: Colin Dwyer
